title: EPISTOLA Dan Pratt
html:
EPISTOLA Dan Pratt

A couple comments on the article “Say It with Words” (XXVIII/1) In Latin, the word order Te amo is at least as likely as the order amo te. Virtually all grammars say the verb was normally at the end of its clause unless some special emphasis was desired. St. Augustine famously wrote “Sero te amavi.” One of my favorite languages for “I love you” is Hungarian: szeretlek, where the -lek ending specifies both the subject “I” and object “you” (and also illustrates vowel harmony). I believe other combinations of subject-object pronouns have no special form.

[Dan Pratt]
